title: Kenya: Health Workers Paralyse Services in Nyeri County
text:
Distressed and without knowledge of what had led to the job boycott, they walked away. 
Only ambulances were allowed in and out of the compounds of the two hospitals. 
PATIENTS MOVED 
Movement and business were minimal, with family members helping their patients into waiting vehicles. 
A majority of the patients were transferred to private hospitals but some were taken home, with their families citing their inability to meet high medical costs at private hospitals. 
Ms Ann Wanja, whose son had been admitted to Nyeri County Referral Hospital with a knee injury, said she intended to take him home. 
"My wish would be to take my son to a private hospital and ensure he gets medical attention but I cannot afford it. We will wait until the strike is over," she said. 
Health workers' representatives who talked to Nation.co.ke vowed to continue with the strike until all their demands are met. 
Besides demanding their July pay, the workers also want the health function, which was devolved, to revert to the national government. 
They are also pushing for promotions and better working conditions. 
Kenya National Union of Nurses Nyeri branch Chairman Alice Nyawira said Kenyans had been denied the right to decent medical services since Health was devolved. 
"Health workers are demotivated and cannot continue working in the poorly equipped hospitals. We will not return to work until we see change," she said. 
Nation.co.ke's efforts to reach the County Health executive secretary for a comment were futile as his phone was switched off. 
Health Chief of Staff Peter Munyua refused to comment, saying he was not authorised to comment on the sensitive issue. Kenya
